prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would. What is the smallest integer $k$ such that $k>1$ and $k$ has remainder $1$ when divided by any of $17,$ $6,$ and $2?$
solution: We can re-write the problem as the following three equations: $$k = 17a+1\\k = 6b+1 \\ k = 2c + 1$$Therefore, $k-1$ is divisible by $17,$ $6,$ and $2.$ The smallest positive value of $k-1$ is thus $$\text{lcm}[17,6,2] = \text{lcm}[17,6] = 17\cdot 6 = 102,$$and so the smallest possible value of $k$ is $k = 102+1 = \boxed{103}.$
gpt_response: Hmm, let's see... So if we divide $k$ by $17,$ $6,$ and $2,$ and in each case we get a remainder of $1, then that means $k$ is one more than a multiple of each of those numbers. That means $k$ has to be one more than a multiple of the least common multiple of $17,$ $6,$ and $2,$ which is $2\cdot3\cdot17=102.$ So the smallest integer $k$ that satisfies all those conditions is $102+1=\boxed{103}.$
solution_prompt: Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to 103?: Hmm, let's see... So if we divide $k$ by $17,$ $6,$ and $2,$ and in each case we get a remainder of $1, then that means $k$ is one more than a multiple of each of those numbers. That means $k$ has to be one more than a multiple of the least common multiple of $17,$ $6,$ and $2,$ which is $2\cdot3\cdot17=102.$ So the smallest integer $k$ that satisfies all those conditions is $102+1=\boxed{103}.$
